question: Question 1 The ordinary differential equation [latex]\frac{d^2u}{dx^2}-2x^2u+\sin x=0[/latex] is
solution: Its solution is of the type u=f(x), i.e., dependent variable is u. Hence, given equation is Linear and Non-Homogeneous.

question: Question 2 The value of [latex]\lim_{x \to \infty } \frac{\sqrt{9x^2+2020}}{x+7}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\lim_{x \to \infty }\frac{3x \sqrt{1+\frac{2020}{x^2}}}{x\left ( 1+\frac{7}{x} \right )}=3[/latex]

question:
Question 3 The integral [latex]\int_{0}^{1}(5x^3+4x^2+3x+2)dx[/latex] is estimated numerically using three alternative methods namely the rectangular, trapezoidal
and Simpson's rules with a common step size. In this context, which one of the following
statement is TRUE?
solution: Because integral is a polynomial of 3rd degree so Simpson's rule will give error free answer.

options.A: Simpsons rule as well as rectangular rule of estimation will give NON-zero error.
options.B:
Simpson's rule, rectangular rule as well as trapezoidal rule of estimation will give
NON-zero error.
options.C: Only the rectangular rule of estimation will given zero error.
options.D: Only Simpson's rule of estimation will give zero error.

question: Question 4 The following partial differential equation is defined for [latex]u:u(x,y)[/latex] [latex]\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}; \; \; y\geq 0;\;x_1\leq x\leq x_2[/latex] The set of auxiliary conditions necessary to solve the equation uniquely, is
solution: Given: DE is [latex]\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}; \; y\geq 0;\; x_1 \leq x\leq x_2[/latex] [latex] \because[/latex] y is given as [latex]\geq 0[/latex] so we take it as time. Hence, above equation is nothing but one-D heat equation which requires one initial condition and two boundary condition.

options.C: two initial conditions and one boundary condition
options.D: one initial condition and two boundary conditions

question:
Question 5 The ratio of the plastic moment capacity of a beam section to its yield moment capacity
is termed as
solution: Ratio of [latex]\frac{M_p}{M_y}=[/latex] Shape factor

question: Question 6 The state of stress represented by Mohr's circle shown in the figure is
solution: In pure shear condition, Mohr's circle has its center at origin.

question:
Question 7 A weightless cantilever beam of span L is loaded as shown in the figure. For the entire
span of the beam, the material properties are identical and the cross-section is rectangular
with constant width. From the flexure-critical perspective, the most economical longitudinal profile of the beam
to carry the given loads amongst the options given below, is
solution: [latex](-PL) + (PL) + (-M_A) = 0[/latex] [latex]M_A = 0[/latex] For most economical, Maximum cross-section is given where maximum bending moment occurs.

question: Question 8 As per IS 456:2000, the pH value of water for concrete mix shall NOT be less than
solution: 1. Minimum pH value of water for concrete = 6.0 As per IS code provision no. 5.4.2, the pH value of water shall not less than 6.0.

question:
Question 9 The traffic starts discharging from an approach at an intersection with the signal turning
green. The constant headway considered from the fourth or fifth headway position is
referred to as
Question 10 Soil deposit formed due to transportation by wind is termed as
solution: Soil deposited by wind is Aeolian soil.

question:
Question 11 A sample of 500 g dry sand, when poured into a 2 litre capacity cylinder which is partially
filled with water, displaces 188 [latex]cm^3[/latex] of water. The density of water is 1 [latex]g/cm^3[/latex]. The specific
gravity of the sand is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_s&=500gm \\ V_s&=188cc \\ \gamma _s&=\frac{W_s}{V_s} \\ G_s&=\frac{\gamma _s}{\gamma _w}\\&=\frac{500/188}{1}=2.66 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 Muskingum method is used in
solution: Muskingum method is used in hydrological channel routing

question: Question 13 Superpassage is a canal cross-drainage structure in which
solution: Cross-section of a super passage

options.A: natural stream water flows with free surface below a canal
options.B: natural stream water flows under pressure below a canal
options.C: canal water flows with free surface below a natural stream
options.D: canal water flows under pressure below a natural stream

question:
Question 14 A triangular direct runoff hydrograph due to a storm has a time base of 90 hours. The
peak flow of 60 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] occurs at 20 hours from the start of the storm. The area of catchment
is 300 [latex]km^2[/latex]. The rainfall excess of the storm (in cm), is
solution: [latex]\left [ \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times 60 m^3/s \times 90 \times 3600s}{300 \times 10^6m^2} \times 100 \right ]cm[/latex]= Rainfall excess Rainfall excess = 3.24 cm

question:
Question 15 The velocity components in the x and y directions for an incompressible flow are given
as u=(-5+6x) and v=-(9+6y), respectively. The equation of the streamline is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given  } \; \; \; & u=-5+6x \\ & v=-(9+6y) \end{aligned} [/latex] Equation of streamline [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{u}&=\frac{dy}{u} \\ \frac{dx}{-5+6x}&=\frac{dy}{-(9+6y)} \\ \text{Integrating it,} \\ \ln(-5+6x)^{1/6}&= -\ln(9+6y)^{1/6}+ \ln C^{1/6}\\ \frac{1}{6} \ln (-5+6x)(9+6y)&=\frac{1}{6} \ln C \\ \text{Take antilog,} \\ (-5 + 6x)(9 + 6y) &= \text{constant} \\ \text{u.v} &= \text{constant} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 16 The relationship between oxygen consumption and equivalent biodegradable organic
removal (i.e. BOD) in a closed container with respect to time is shown in the figure. Assume that the rate of oxygen consumption is directly proportional to the amount of
degradable organic matter and is expressed as [latex]\frac{dL_t}{dt}=-kL_t[/latex], where, [latex]L_t[/latex] (in mg/litre) is the oxygen equivalent of the organics remaining at time t and [latex]k[/latex] (in [latex]d^{-1}[/latex]) is the degradation
rate constant. [latex]L_0[/latex] is the oxygen of organic matter at time, t = 0. In the above context, the correct expression is
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dL_t}{dt}&=-kL_t \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{dL_t}{L_t} &=-kdt \\ \Rightarrow \; \int_{L_o}^{L_t} \frac{dL_t}{L_t} &=-k\int_{0}^{t}dt \\ \Rightarrow \; \ln \left ( \frac{L_t}{L_o} \right ) &=-kt \\ \Rightarrow \; L_t&=L_o e^{-kt} \end{aligned}[/latex] The term [latex]L_o[/latex] in the above equation represents
the total oxygen equivalent of the organics at
time [latex]t=0[/latex], while [latex]L_t[/latex] represents the amount
remaining at time [latex]t[/latex], and decays exponentially
with time. The amount of oxygen used in the consumption
of the organics, the [latex]{BOD}_t[/latex]
 can be found from the [latex]L_t[/latex] value. The difference between the value [latex]L_o[/latex] and [latex]L_t[/latex] is
the oxygen equivalent consumed, or the BOD
exerted. Mathematically [latex]{BOD}_t=(L_o-L_t)=L_o-L_oe^{-kt}=L_o(1-e^{-kt})[/latex]

question:
Question 17 A gas contains two types of suspended particle having average sizes of 2 [latex]\mu m[/latex] and
50 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. Amongst the options given below, the most suitable pollution control strategy
for removal of these particles is
solution:
Large size particles should be removed first, hence answer should be (A). Theoretically, gravitational settling chamber
should be able to remove particulates down to 5
or 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex], but in actual they are not practical for
removal of particles much less than 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex] in
size. Hence, gravitational settling chamber is most
suitable choice for removal of suspended particles
of size 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. After the removal of 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex] size particles, to
remove 2 [latex]\mu m[/latex] size particles, we use fabric bag
filter. Note: Fabric bag filter has high collection
efficiency for all particle sizes, especially for
particles smaller than 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex] in diameter.

options.A: settling chamber followed by bag filter
options.B: electrostatic precipitator followed by venturi scrubber
options.C: electrostatic precipitator followed by cyclonic separator
options.D: bag filter followed by electrostatic precipitator

question:
Question 18 A fair (unbiased) coin is tossed 15 times. The probability of getting exactly 8 Heads
(round off to three decimal places), is ________.
solution: [latex]P(H)=\frac{1}{2} [/latex] [latex]P(T)=\frac{1}{2} [/latex] Probability of getting exactly 8 heads out of 15 trial [latex]={^{15}C_8}\left [ \frac{1}{2} \right ]^8 \times \left [ \frac{1}{2} \right ]^{15-8}=0.196[/latex]

question:
Question 19 The maximum applied load on a cylindrical concrete specimen of diameter 150 mm and
length 300 mm tested as per the split tensile strength test guidelines of IS 5816 : 1999
is 157 kN. The split tensile strength (in MPa, round off to one decimal place) of the
specimen is _______.
solution: P = 157 kN D = 150 mm L = 300 mm In split tensile strength test, split tensile strength of concrete [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{et}&=\frac{2P}{\pi DL}=\frac{2 \times 157000}{\pi \times 150 \times 300}\\ &=2.22 N/mm^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 20 For an axle load of 15 tonne on a road, the Vehicle Damage Factor (round off to two
decimal places), in terms of the standard axle load of 8 tonne, is _________.
solution: Axle load = 15 T Standard axle load = 8 T [latex]VDF=\left [ \frac{15}{8} \right ]^4=12.35[/latex]

question:
Question 21 24-h traffic count at a road section was observed to be 1000 vehicles on a Tuesday
in the month of July. If daily adjustment factor for Tuesday is 1.121 and monthly
adjustment factor for July is 0.913, the Annual Average Daily Traffic (in veh/day, round
off to the nearest integer) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{24} &=1000 veh \; (Tuesday) \\ DAF&=1.121 \\ AADT&=? \\ MAF&= 0.913\\ T_{week}&=T_{24} \times DAF \\ &=1000 \times 1.121=1121 \\ AADT&=MAF \times ADT \\ &= 0.913 \times 1121\\ &= 1023.473\\ &=1023 VPD \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 22 A soil has dry weight of 15.5 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex], specific gravity of 2.65 and degree of saturation
of 72%. Considering the unit weight of water as 10 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex], the water content of the soil
(in %, round off to two decimal places) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _d&=15.5 kN/m^3\\ G&=2.65\\ S&=72\% \\ \gamma _d&=\frac{G\gamma _w}{1+e}\\ &=\frac{2.65 \times 10}{1+e}=15.5\\ e&=0.7096\\ w&=\frac{Se}{G}=\frac{0.72 \times 0.7096}{2.65}=0.1928\\ w&=19.28\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 A one-dimensional consolidation test is carried out on a standard 19 mm thick clay
sample. The oedometer's deflection gauge indicates a reading of 2.1 mm, just
before removal of the load, without allowing any swelling. The void ratio is 0.62
at this stage. The initial void ratio (round off to two decimal places) of the standard
specimen is ________.
solution: Oedometer reading = 2.1 mm 16 mm thick, e = 0.62 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\Delta H}{H_0}&=\frac{\Delta e}{1+e_0}=\frac{e_0-e_f}{1+e_0} \\ \frac{2.1 mm}{19mm} &=\frac{e_0-0.62}{1+e_0} \\ e_0&=0.82 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 24 Velocity distribution in a boundary layer is given by [latex]\frac{u}{U_\infty }=\sin \left ( \frac{\pi}{2}\frac{y}{\delta } \right )[/latex], where [latex]u[/latex] is the
velocity at vertical coordinate [latex]y, U_\infty[/latex] is the free stream velocity and [latex]\delta[/latex] is the boundary
layer thickness. The values of [latex] U_\infty[/latex] and [latex]\delta[/latex] are 0.3 m/s and 1.0 m, respectively. The velocity gradient [latex]\left ( \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \right )[/latex] (in [latex]s^{-1}[/latex], round off to two decimal places) at y= 0, is ________.
solution: Given: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{u}{u_\infty }&=\sin \left ( \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta }\right )\\ u_\infty &=0.3 m/s\\ \delta &=1m\\ \frac{du}{dy}&=\frac{d}{dy}u_\infty \cdot \sin\left ( \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta } \right )\\ &=\frac{u_\infty \cdot \pi}{2\delta } \cos \left ( \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta } \right )\\ \text{At y=0 and} & \; \delta=1 \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{du}{dy} \end{matrix}\right|_{y=0}&=\frac{0.3 \pi}{2(1)} \cos \left ( \frac{\pi}{2}\frac{0}{1} \right )\\ &=0.47 s^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 25 Two identically sized primary settling tanks receive water for Type-I settling (discrete
particles in dilute suspension) under laminar flow conditions. The surface overflow rate
(SOR) maintained in the two tanks are 30 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex] and 15 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex]. The lowest diameters
of the particles, which shall be settled out completely under SORs of 30 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex] and 15 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex] are
designated as [latex]d_{30}[/latex] and [latex]d_{15}[/latex] respectively. The ratio [latex]\frac{d_{30}}{d_{15}}[/latex]
(round off to two decimal places),
is __________.
solution: For type-I setting, Stokes law is applicable. [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&\propto d^2 \\ \frac{d_{30}^2}{d_{15}^2}&=\frac{30}{15}=2 \\ \frac{d_{30}}{d_{15}}&=\sqrt{2}=1.41 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 An ordinary differential equation is given below [latex]6\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}+\frac{dy}{dx}-y=0[/latex] The general solution of the above equation (with constant [latex]C_1 \; and \; C_2[/latex]), is
Question 27 A 4x4 matrix [P] is given below [latex][P]=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 &3 &0 \\ -2& 3 & 0 & 4\\ 0& 0& 6 & 1\\ 0& 0& 1& 6 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The eigen values of [P] are
solution: |P|= 70 and Trace (P) = 15 So, only option, (1, 2, 5, 7) satisfies.

question:
Question 28 A prismatic linearly elastic bar of length, L, cross-sectional area A, and made up of a
material with Young's modulus E, is subjected to axial tensile force as shown in the
figures. When the bar is subjected to axial tensile force [latex]P_1\; and\; P_2[/latex], the strain energies
stored in the bar are [latex]U_1\; and\; U_2[/latex], respectively. If U is the strain energy stored in the same bar when subjected to an axial tensile force ([latex]P_1 + P_2[/latex]), the correct relationship is
solution: [latex](P_1+P_2)^2 \gt P_1^2+P_2^2[/latex] [latex]U \gt U_1+U_2[/latex]

question:
Question 29 The planar structure RST shown in the figure is roller-supported at S and pin-supported
at R. Members RS and ST have uniform flexural rigidity (EI) and S is a rigid joint. Consider
only bending deformation and neglect effects of self-weight and axial stiffening When the structure is subjected to a concentrated horizontal load P at the end T, the
magnitude of rotation at the support R, is
solution: [latex]\theta _R=\frac{(PL/2)L}{6EI}[/latex] [latex]\theta _R=\frac{PL^2}{12EI}[/latex]

question:
Question 30 Joints I, J, K, L, Q and M of the frame shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale)
are pins. Continuous members IQ and IJ are connected through a pin at N. Continuous
members JM and KQ are connected through a pin at P. The frame has hinge supports
at joints R and S. The loads acting at joints I, J and K are along the negative Y direction
and the loads acting at joints I, M are along the positive X direction. The magnitude of the horizontal component of reaction (in kN) at S, is
solution: Remove hinge at support S and replace it with roller support as shown in the figure. Step One : Find coordinates of all the points where forces are acting [latex]\begin{aligned} y_I&=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta \\ y_J&=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta \\ y_K&=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta \\ x_L&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \\ x_M&=5\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \\ x_S&=6\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \end{aligned}[/latex] Step Two: Find virtual displacements of all the points [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta y_I&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta \\ \delta y_J&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta \\ \delta y_K&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta \\ \delta x_L&=-\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta \\ \delta x_M&=-5\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta \\ \delta x_S&=-6\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Step Three : Use principle of virtual work to find unknown horizontal force [latex]H_s[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \delta U=0[/latex] [latex]=[-10 \times \sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta ] \times 3 + [-10 \times -\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta ] +[-10 \times -5\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta ] - [-H_S \times -6\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta ][/latex] [latex]H_S=\frac{30\sqrt{2} \cos \theta +10\sqrt{2} \sin \theta +50\sqrt{2} \sin \theta}{6\sqrt{2} \sin \theta}[/latex] Substituting, [latex]\theta =45^{\circ},\; H_S=\frac{90}{6}=15kN[/latex] Note : Sign conventions If a force acts along positive x or positive y-axis, take it as positive. If a force acts along negative x or negative y-axis, take it as negative.

question: Question 31 The flow-density relationship of traffic on a headway is shown in the figure. The correct representation of speed-density relationship of the traffic on this highway is

Question 32 Group-I gives a list of test methods for evaluating properties of aggregates. Group-II
gives the list of properties to be evaluated. The correct match of test methods under Group-I to properties under Group-II, is
solution:
Soundness test is done to evaluate
resistance against weathering of aggregate. Crushing test is done to evaluate strength of
aggregate. Los angles abrasion test is to evaluate
hardness of aggregate. Stripping value test is to evaluate ratio of
uncovered area observed to the total area of
aggregate. The test is conducted to
determine the effects of moisture upon the
adhesion of binding material.

question:
Question 33 For the hottest month of the year at the proposed airport site, the monthly mean of the
average daily temperature is 39[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. The monthly mean of the maximum daily temperature
is 48[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] for the same month of the year. From the given information, the calculated Airport
Reference Temperature (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]), is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_a&=39^{\circ}C\\ T_m&=48^{\circ}C\\ ATR&=T_a+\left ( \frac{T_m-T_a}{3} \right )\\ &=39+\left ( \frac{48-39}{3}\right )\\&=42^{\circ}C \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 34 Permeability tests were carried out on the samples collected from two different layers
as shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The relevant horizontal ([latex]k_h[/latex]) and vertical
([latex]k_v[/latex]) coefficients of permeability are indicated for each layer. The ratio of the equivalent horizontal to vertical coefficients of permeability, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{k_{eq.H}}{k_{eq.V}}&=\frac{\frac{\Sigma K_iZ_i}{\Sigma Z_i}}{\frac{\Sigma Z_i}{\Sigma \frac{Z_i}{K_i}}}\\ &=\frac{\frac{4.4 \times 10^{-3} \times 3 +6 \times 10^{-1} \times 4}{7}}{\frac{7}{\frac{3}{4 \times 10^{-3}}+\frac{4}{5.5 \times 10^{-1}}}}\\ &=\frac{0.3447}{9.24 \times 10{-3}}=37.29 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 35 A 10 m high slope of dry clay soil (unit weight = 20 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]), with a slope angle of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex]
and the circular slip surface, is shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The weight
of the slip wedge is denoted by W. The undrained unit cohesion ([latex]c_u[/latex]) is 60 kPa. The factor of safety of the slope against slip failure, is
solution: As per GATE Official Answer Key MTA (Marks to All) Consider unit length of slope Area of circular arc [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{\theta }{360} \times \pi r^2-\text{Area of }\Delta \\ &=\frac{90}{360} \times \pi \times 10^2-\frac{1}{2}\times 10 \times 10\\ &=28.54m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Height of wedge}& = \text{Volume} \times \gamma \\ &=(\text{Area} \times 1) \times \gamma \\ &=28.54 \times 1 \times 20\\ &=570.8 kN\\ FOS&=\frac{M_R}{M_0}\\ &=\frac{[c \times (r\theta )]\times r}{W \times x}\\ &=\frac{60 \times 10 \times \frac{\pi}{1} \times 10}{570.8 \times 4.48}\\ &=3.68 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 36 Crops are grown in a field having soil, which has field capacity of 30% and permanent
wilting point of 13%. The effective depth of root zone is 80 cm. Irrigation water is supplied
when the average soil moisture drops to 20%. Consider density of the soil as 1500 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex]
and density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex]. If the daily consumptive use of water for the crops
is 2 mm, the frequency of irrigating the crops (in days), is
solution: As per GATE Official Answer Key MTA (Marks to All) FC=30% PWP=13% [latex]\begin{aligned} d_w&=\frac{\gamma _d}{\gamma _w}d \times (FC-OMC) \\ &= \frac{1500}{1000}\times 80 (0.3-0.2)\\ &= 12cm=120mm \end{aligned}[/latex] Consumptive use = 2 mm/day So, frequency of irrigation =120/2 = 60day

question:
Question 37 Alkalinity of water, in equivalent/litre (eq/litre), is given by [latex]\{HCO_3^-\}+2\{CO_3^{2-}\}+\{OH^-\}-\{H^+\}[/latex] where, { } represents concentration in mol/litre. For a water sample, the concentration
of [latex]HCO_3^? = 2 \times 10^{-3}[/latex] mol/litre, [latex]CO_3^{2-} = 3.04 \times 10^{-4}[/latex] mol/litre and the pH of water = 9.0.
The atomic weights are : Ca = 40; C = 12; and O = 16. If the concentration of [latex]OH^-[/latex]
and [latex]H^+[/latex] are NEGLECTED, the alkalinity of the water sample (in mg/litre as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex]), is
solution: Alkalinity of water sample is due to presence of [latex][HCO_3^-][/latex] and [latex][HCO_3^{2-}][/latex] Total alkalinity = 1 mole of [latex][HCO_3^-][/latex] + 2 mole of [latex][HCO_3^{2-}][/latex] in terms of [latex]CaCO_3[/latex] [latex]=(2 \times 10^{-3} \times 50 +2 \times 3.04 \times 10^{-4} \times 50) \times 10^3 mg/l[/latex] [latex]=130.4 mg/l \; as \; CaCO_3[/latex]

question:
Question 38 A theodolite was set up at a station P. The angle of depression to a vane 2 m above
the foot of a staff held at another station Q was [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex]. The horizontal distance between
stations P and Q is 20 m. The staff reading at a benchmark S of RL 433.050 m
is 2.905 m. Neglecting the errors due to curvature and refraction, the RL of the station Q (in m), is

Question 39 The Fourier series to represent [latex]x-x^2[/latex] for [latex]- \pi \leq x\leq \pi[/latex] is given by [latex]x-x^2=\frac{a_0}{2}+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }a_n \cos nx +\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }b_n \sin nx[/latex] The value of [latex]a_0[/latex] (round off to two decimal places), is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} a_0&=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}f(x)dx\\ &=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} (x-x^2)dx\\ &=\frac{-1}{\pi}\int_{0}^{\pi}2x^2 dx\\ &=\frac{-1}{\pi}\left ( \frac{2x^3}{3} \right )_0^{\pi}\\ &=-\frac{2}{3 \pi}[\pi^3]=\frac{-2 \pi^2}{3}\\ &=-6.58 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 The diameter and height of a right circular cylinder are 3 cm and 4 cm, respectively.
The absolute error in each of these two measurements is 0.2 cm. The absolute error in
the computed volume (in [latex]cm^3[/latex], round off to three decimal places), is _______.
solution: Let diameter, x = 3 and height = y = 4 and error= [latex]\pm 0.2[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V&= \pi\left ( \frac{x}{2} \right )^2y=\frac{\pi x^2 y}{4}\\ V&=f(x,y) \\ dV&= \left ( \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} \right )dx +\left ( \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} \right )dy\\ dV&= \left ( \frac{1}{2}\pi xy \right )dx +\left ( \frac{\pi x^2}{4} \right )dy\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \pi \times 3 \times 4 \times (0.2)+\frac{\pi}{4} \times (3)^2 \times (0.2)\\ &= 1.65 \pi\\ &=1.65 \times 3.14=5.18 \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e., absolute error = |5.18| = 5.18

question:
Question 41 A concrete beam of span 15 m, 150 mm wide and 350 mm deep is prestressed with
a parabolic cable as shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). Coefficient of friction
for the cable is 0.35, and coefficient of wave effect is 0.0015 per metre. If the cable is tensioned from one end only, the percentage loss (round off to one decimal
place) in the cable force due to friction, is ________.
solution: Jacking from one end x = L = 15 m Wobble correction factor, K = 0.0015 Coefficient of friction = 0.35 = [latex]\mu[/latex] P = Not given [latex]p_0[/latex] = Unknown Change of gradient, [latex]\alpha = \tan \alpha =\frac{8h}{L}=\frac{8 \times 120}{15000}=0.064[/latex] % loss of stress in steel due to friction [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{p_0(Kx+\mu \alpha )}{p_0} \times 100\\ &=(0.0015 \times 15+0.35 \times 0.064)\times 100 \\ &= 4.49\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 42 The plane truss has hinge supports at P and W and is subjected to the horizontal forces
as shown in the figure. Representing the tensile force with '+' sign and the compressive force with '-' sign, the
force in member XW (in kN, round off to the nearest integer), is _________.
solution: Force in PQ Considering the section above (1) - (1) Taking moment about 'R' [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{RL}&=0\\ (10 \times 4)+(10 \times 8)&+F_{PQ} \times 4=0\\ F_{PQ}&=-\frac{120}{4}\\ &=-30kN=30kN (Comp.) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 The cross-section of the reinforced concrete beam having an effective depth of 500 mm
is shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The grades of concrete and steel used
are M35 and Fe550, respectively. The area of tension reinforcement is 400 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. It is
given that corresponding to 0.2% proof stress, the material safety factor is 1.15 and
the yield strain of Fe550 steel is 0.0044. As per IS 456:2000, the limiting depth (in mm, round off to the nearest integer) of the
neutral axis measured from the extreme compression fiber, is ________.
solution: For a RCC T-Beam (For limiting depth of neutral axis) Considering d=500mm [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{0.0035}{x_{u,lim}}&=\frac{0.0044}{d-x_{u,lim}}\\ d-x_{u,lim}&=\frac{0.0044}{0.0035} \times x_{u,lim}\\ 35 \times 500&=35x_{u,lim}+44x_{u,lim}\\ &=79x_{u,lim}\\ x_{u,lim}&=\frac{35 \times 500}{79}\\ &=221.52 mm \end{aligned}[/latex] Limiting depth of neutral axis [latex]x_{0,lim}=221.52mm[/latex]

question:
Question 44 Two steel plates are lap jointed in a workshop using 6 mm thick fillet weld as shown
in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The ultimate strength of the weld is 410 MPa. As per Limit State Design is IS 800 : 2007, the design capacity (in kN, round off to
three decimal places) of the welded connection, is _______.
solution: Design capacity of welded connection [latex]P_s=f_b \times l_{eff}\times t_t[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=\frac{410}{\sqrt{3} \times 1.25} \times 520 \times 0.7 \times 6 \\ &= \frac{716352}{\sqrt{3}}=413586N\\ &= 413.586kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 The design speed of a two-lane two-way road is 60 km/h and the longitudinal coefficient
of friction is 0.36. The reaction time of a driver is 2.5 seconds. Consider acceleration
due to gravity as 9.8 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. The intermediate sight distance (in m, round off to the nearest
integer) required for the load is ________
solution: Given : f = 0.36; v = 60 km; g = 9.8 [latex]m/s^2;\; t_R=2.5s[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} SSD&= \left ( 0.278Vt_R+\frac{V^2}{254f} \right )\\ &= 0.278 \times 60 \times 2.5 +\frac{60^2}{254 \times 0.36}\\ &= 41.7+39.37=81m\\ ISD &=2 \times SSD\\ &=81 \times 2=162m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 46 A footing of size 2m x 2m transferring a pressure of 200 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex], is placed at a depth
of 1.5 m below the ground as shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The clay
stratum is normally consolidated. The clay has specific gravity of 2.65 and compression
index of 0.3. Considering 2:1 (vertical to horizontal) method of load distribution and [latex]\gamma _w = 10 kN/m^3[/latex],
the primary consolidation settlement (in mm, round off to two decimal places) of the clay
stratum is _________.
solution: For clay layer, [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _{sat}&=\left ( \frac{G+e}{1+e} \right )\gamma _w \\ &= \left ( \frac{2.65+1}{1+e} \right )10=17kNm^3\\ e_0&=1.357 \\ H_0&=1.5m \\ (\bar{\sigma _0})_{c-c}&=[2\gamma _d+0.5\gamma _{sat}+0.75\gamma _{sat}]-1.25\gamma _w \\ &= (2 \times 15+0.5 \times 15+0.75 \times 17)-1.25 \times 10\\ &= 39.25kN/m^2\\ \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=\frac{Force}{Area} \\ &= \frac{qB^2}{(B+2nZ)^2}\\ &=\frac{200 \times 2 \times 2}{(2 \times 2 \times \frac{1}{2} \times 1.75)^2}\\ &=56.88kN/m^2\\ \Delta H&=\frac{H_0C_c}{1+e_0} \log \left ( \frac{\bar{\sigma _0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma }}{\bar{\sigma_0 }} \right )\\ &=\frac{1.5 \times 0.3}{1+1.357} \log \left ( \frac{39.25+56.88}{39.25} \right )\\ &=74.27mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A constant head permeability test was conducted on a soil specimen under a hydraulic
gradient of 2.5. The soil specimen has specific gravity of 2.65 and saturated water content
of 20%. If the coefficient of permeability of the soil is 0.1 cm/s, the seepage velocity
(in cm/s, round off to two decimal places) through the soil specimen is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Void ratio,}\; e&=\frac{wG}{s}\\ &=\frac{0.2 \times 2.65}{1}=0.53\\ \text{Porosity,}\; n&=\frac{e}{1+e}=0.3464\\ \text{Seepage velocity,}\; V_s&=\frac{v}{n}=\frac{k_i}{n}\\ &=\frac{0.1 \times 2.5}{0.3464}=0.72 cm/sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 A 5 m high vertical wall has a saturated clay backfill. The saturation unit weight and
cohesion of clay are [latex]18kN/m^3[/latex] and 20 kPa, respectively. The angle of internal friction
of clay is zero. In order to prevent development of tension zone, the height of the wall
is required to be increased. Dry sand is used as backfill above the clay for the increased
portion of the wall. The unit weight and angle of internal friction of sand are [latex]16kN/m^3[/latex]
and [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex], respectively. Assume that the back of the wall is smooth and top of the backfill
is horizontal. To prevent the development of tension zone, the minimum height (in m,
round off to one decimal place) by which the wall has to be raised, is __________.
solution: To prevent tension crack, [latex]\begin{aligned} q&=\frac{2c}{\sqrt{k_a}}=\frac{2 \times 20}{1}=40\\ q&=\gamma _d x=40\\ x&=\frac{40}{16}=2.5m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 49 A cast iron pipe of diameter 600 mm and length 400 m carries water from a tank and
discharges freely into air at a point 4.5 m below the water surface in the tank. The friction
factor of the pipe is 0.018. Consider acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. The velocity
of the flow in pipe (in m/s, round off to two decimal places) is __________.
solution: Apply energy equation between (1) and (2) [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{\rho g} +\frac{V_1^2}{2g}+z_1&= \frac{P_2}{\rho g} +\frac{V_2^2}{2g}+z_2+h_f\\ 4.5&=\frac{flV^2}{2gD}+0.5\frac{V^2}{2g}+\frac{V^2}{2g} \\ 4.5&=\frac{(0.018)(400)V^2}{2(9.81)(0.6)}+\frac{1.5V^2}{2g} \\ 4.5&=\frac{12V^2}{2g}+\frac{1.5V^2}{2g} \\ V^2&=6.54 \\ V&=2.557 m/s\simeq 2.56m/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 A hydraulic jump occurs, in a triangular (V-shaped) channel with side slopes 1:1 (vertical
to horizontal). The sequent depths are 0.5 m and 1.5 m. The flow rate (in [latex]m^3/s[/latex], round
off to two decimal places) in the channel is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\frac{1}{2} \times 2Y \times Y =Y^2 \\ \bar{Y} &=\frac{Y}{3} \end{aligned} [/latex] For a horizontal and frictionless channel Specific Force (F) [latex] =A\bar{Y}+\frac{Q^2}{Ag}=constant [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Y^2\left ( \frac{Y}{3} \right )+\frac{Q^2}{(Y^2)g}=constant[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; \frac{Y^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{gY^2}=constant [/latex] If [latex]Y_1[/latex] and [latex]Y_2[/latex] are conjugate depth [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{Y_1^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{gY_1^2} &= \frac{Y_2^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{gY_2}\\ \frac{0.5^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{g \times 0.5^2}&=\frac{1.5^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{g \times 1.5^2} \\ \frac{1.5^3}{3}-\frac{0.5^3}{3}&=\frac{Q^2}{g}\left ( \frac{1}{0.5^2}-\frac{1}{1.5^2} \right ) \\ Q&=1.728 m^3/sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 51 A concrete dam holds 10 m of static water as shown in the figure (not drawn to the
scale). The uplift assumed to vary linearly from full hydrostatic head at the heel, to zero
at the toe of dam. The coefficient of friction between the dam and foundation soil is 0.45.
Specific weights of concrete and water are 24 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex] and 9.81 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex], respectively. For NO sliding condition, the required minimum base width B (in m, round off to two
decimal places) is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mu &=0.45\\ \gamma_{conc} &=24 kN/m^3\\ B_{min. sliding}&=\frac{10}{0.45(2.4-1)}\\ &=15.873m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 The ion product of water ([latex]pK_w[/latex]) is 14. If a rain water sample has a pH of 5.6, the
concentration of [latex]OH^-[/latex] in the sample (in [latex]10^{-9}[/latex] mol/litre, round off to one decimal place),
is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} pH+pOH&=14\\ pOH&=14-5.6=8.4\\ -log[OH^-]&=8.4\\ [OH^-]&=10^{-8.4}\; moles/lt\\ &=10^{-8.4+9} \times 10^{-9}\; moles/lt\\ &=3.98 \times 10^{-9} \; moles/lt \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 53 A waste to energy plant burns dry solid waste of composition : Carbon = 35%, Oxygen = 26%, Hydrogen = 10%, Sulphur = 6%, Nitrogen = 3% and Inerts = 20%. Burning rate is 1000 tonnes/d. Oxygen in air by weight is 23%. Assume complete
conversion of Carbon to [latex]CO_2[/latex], Hydrogen to [latex]H_2O[/latex], Sulphur to [latex]SO_2[/latex] and Nitrogen to [latex]NO_2[/latex]. Given Atomic weighs : H=1, C=12, N=14, O=16, S=32. The stoichiometric (theoretical) amount of air (in tonnes/d, round off to the nearest integer)
required for complete burning of this waste, is __________.
solution: [latex]\underbrace{C}_{12}\underbrace{O}_{2}\rightarrow CO_2[/latex] Oxygen required for 350 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{12}\times 350=933.33[/latex] [latex]\underbrace{4H}_{4}+\underbrace{O_2}_{32}\rightarrow 2H_2O[/latex] Oxygen required for 100 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{4}\times 100=800[/latex] [latex]\underbrace{S}_{32}+\underbrace{O_2}_{32}\rightarrow SO_2[/latex] Oxygen required for 60 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{32}\times 60=60[/latex] [latex]\underbrace{N}_{14}+\underbrace{O}_{32}\rightarrow NO_2[/latex] Oxygen required for 30 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{14}\times 30=68.57[/latex] Total [latex]O_2[/latex] = 1861.9 tonne/day Available [latex]O_2[/latex] in waste = 260 tonne/day Required =1861.9-260=1601.9 tinne/day Amount of air required [latex]=\frac{1601.9}{0.23}=6964.78 \; \text{tonne/day} \simeq 6965 \; \text{tonne/day}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 A sample of water contain an organic compound [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8[/latex] at a concentration of [latex]10^{-3}[/latex] mol/litre.
Given that the atomic weight of C = 12 g/mol, H = 1 g/mol, and O = 16 g/mol, the
theoretical oxygen demand of water (in g of [latex]O_2[/latex] per litre, round off to two decimal places),
is ___________
solution: [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8[/latex] of conc [latex]10^{-3}[/latex] moles/lt required [latex]O_2[/latex] (in gm/lt) [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8 +8O_2\rightarrow 8CO_2+8H_2O[/latex] 1 mole of [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8[/latex] requires 8 moles of [latex]O_2[/latex] for its decomposition [latex]\begin{aligned} 240 gm &= 128 gm\\ 10^{-3} moles&=8 \times 10^{-3}moles \\ &= 8 \times 10^{-3} \times 32\\ &= 0.256 gm/lt \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 A theodolite is set up at station A. The RL of instrument axis is 212.250 m. The angle
of elevation to the top of a 4 m long staff, held vertical at station B, is [latex]7^{\circ}[/latex]. The horizontal
distance between station A and B is 400 m. Neglecting the errors due to curvature of

__________

  [latex] \frac{f\left(f\left(f(x)\right)\right)}{f(x)}[/latex] is equal to ______

Question 61 Nominal interest rate is defined as the amount paid by the borrower to the lender for using the borrowed amount for a specific period of time. Real interest rate calculated on the basis of actual value (inflation-adjusted), is approximately equal to the difference between nominal rate and expected rate of inflation in the economy. Which of the following assertions is best supported by the above information?

options.A: Under high inflation, real interest rate is low and borrowers get benefited
options.B: Under low inflation, real interest rate is high and borrowers get benefited
options.C: Under high inflation, real interest rate is low and lenders get benefited
options.D: Under low inflation, real interest rate is low and borrowers get benefited
